item.title: In Which a Ghostly Visitor Returns
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:

And what is the Gold Line?Ã¢â‚¬Â Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sort of a streetcar,… Continue reading In Which a Ghostly Visitor Returns

The post In Which a Ghostly Visitor Returns appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
March 15, 2007
Los Angeles

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, dear boy, I suppose you thought you were through.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, I did.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good grief! Do you see this bridge over the Gold Line? It looks like itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s held up with hairpins and spit!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Saliva, dear boy. And what is the Gold Line?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sort of a streetcar, except it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t run on the street.Ã¢â‚¬Â

She leaned back in her ghostly chair. Ã¢â‚¬Å“And what did you think of our little year?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I was quite wrong, wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t I?Ã¢â‚¬Â

She merely nodded.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You could have at least told me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Dear boy, you needed to find out for yourself.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“OK, so there were movie theaters in Los Angeles.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And there were comics in the paper.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Little Nemo is one of my favorites.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t believe all the domestic violence. Awful stuff.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“It was terrible,Ã¢â‚¬Â she said.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And getting a divorce was so difficult.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“That was horrible,Ã¢â‚¬Â she said.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And the rotten doctors, the fakes and charlatans, dirty restaurants, the drinking and alcoholism. The exploding gasoline stoves.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well,Ã¢â‚¬Â she said chidingly, Ã¢â‚¬Å“you didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t write very much about people who were nice. You newspaper folks never do.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Most of all, we havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t changed very much, have we? I mean, look at our problems with transportation… with sanitation… with growth… with housing… immigration… ethnic discrimination… education… polluting the ocean. A century later, the Police Department is still pleading for more officers. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the same story, with different details, that we had in 1947.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And why do you think that is?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“MaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢am, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a short question with a long answer. You could tell me, couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I could.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“But youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not going to, because I have to figure it out for myself, is that it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

She nodded.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll miss all of you so much.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You know where to find us,Ã¢â‚¬Â she said.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Was it a kinder, simpler time?Ã¢â‚¬Â I asked.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Maybe in some ways, but mostly no.Ã¢â‚¬Â And then she paused for a moment. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Go take a picture of your bridge. It hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t fallen down yet, has it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nope, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s still there. Or at least some bridge is still there.Ã¢â‚¬Â

I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know what else to say: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks for everything.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You are most welcome. And thank you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

And then she was gone.

item.title: An Unfortunate Loophole
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:
Jan. 18, 1907 San Francisco In what is surely an embarrassing and awkward oversight, the California Constitution only prevents Ã¢â‚¬Å“MongolianÃ¢â‚¬Â children from attending white public schools when separate campuses have been created. The problem, legislators have discovered, is that the Japanese arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Mongolians and feel they somehow have the right to go to school with… Continue reading An Unfortunate Loophole

The post An Unfortunate Loophole appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
Jan. 18, 1907
San Francisco

In what is surely an embarrassing and awkward oversight, the California Constitution only prevents Ã¢â‚¬Å“MongolianÃ¢â‚¬Â children from attending white public schools when separate campuses have been created. The problem, legislators have discovered, is that the Japanese arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Mongolians and feel they somehow have the right to go to school with everyone else.

The case before the Legislature and San Francisco officials involves 10-year-old Keikeiki Aoki, who has been barred from the Redding public schools by Principal Mary A. Deane. In a unanimous ruling, the California Supreme Court has issued a writ ordering Deane to show cause as to why she should not admit Keikeiki to school.

Deane has responded that Ã¢â‚¬Å“she was acting under the law of the state and in pursuance of a resolution passed by the Board of Education that Japanese pupils cannot attend any public school except the Oriental school for Mongolians and Indians,Ã¢â‚¬Â The Times says.

In an attempt to resolve the impasse, San Francisco City Atty. Burke is rushing to Sacramento to urge the Legislature to pass an amendment to the state Constitution substituting the word Ã¢â‚¬Å“AsiaticÃ¢â‚¬Â for Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mongolian.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“As the Legislature is unanimously against admitting Japanese children to the public schools, this amendment could be rushed through in a couple of days,Ã¢â‚¬Â The Times says.

The proposed wording: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And also to establish separate schools for Indian children, Japanese children, Malay children, Korean children and all children of the Mongolian race. When such separate schools are established, Indian, Chinese, Malay, Korean, Japanese and all Mongolian children must not be admitted into any other school.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Remind me again about how the past was a kinder, simpler time, please. I keep forgetting.

Lmharnisch.com
Lmharnisch.blogspot.com
E-mail: lmharnisch (AT) gmail.com

The post An Unfortunate Loophole appeared first on 1947 Project.

item.title: No Christ in Christmas? Good Lord!
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:
Dec. 14, 1907 Los Angeles The madman who calls himself the superintendent of the Los Angeles schools has touched off an absolute firestorm of anger by ordering teachers not to mention Christ during Christmas pageants or other festivities.

The post No Christ in Christmas? Good Lord! appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
Dec. 14, 1907
Los Angeles

The madman who calls himself the superintendent of the Los Angeles schools has touched off an absolute firestorm of anger by ordering teachers not to mention Christ during Christmas pageants or other festivities.

item.title: Pi Phidelity
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:
Oct. 30, 1907 Los Angeles The young men of Los Angeles High School have issued a direct challenge to the Board of Education, defying its authority by enlisting fraternity members despite a ban issued last year. The chief offenders are the Pi Phis, who just added seven members, The Times says.

The post Pi Phidelity appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
Oct. 30, 1907
Los Angeles

The young men of Los Angeles High School have issued a direct challenge to the Board of Education, defying its authority by enlisting fraternity members despite a ban issued last year.

The chief offenders are the Pi Phis, who just added seven members, The Times says.

The post Pi Phidelity appeared first on 1947 Project.

item.title: Oh, You Poor Things
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:
July 11, 1907 Los Angeles Among the presentations at the current educators convention is a seminar on teaching the arts. If you have ever attended a colloquium on arts education or listened to arts educators, these comments from another era sound depressingly familiar, and for all the progress that may have been made, we have… Continue reading Oh, You Poor Things

The post Oh, You Poor Things appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
July 11, 1907
Los Angeles

Among the presentations at the current educators convention is a seminar on teaching the arts. If you have ever attended a colloquium on arts education or listened to arts educators, these comments from another era sound depressingly familiar, and for all the progress that may have been made, we have learned so little.

Of course, there are some chestnuts, such as all good art is calming, uplifting and tames the most savage of us; that art only exists if it is useful.

The post Oh, You Poor Things appeared first on 1947 Project.

item.title: A Page From Dickens
item.dc:creator: Larry Harnish
item.description:
For some time, the teachers at the Casco Street School had been concerned about the pupils from the nearby Christian Orphanage. But finally the problems became too great to ignore.

The post A Page From Dickens appeared first on 1947 Project.
